content.description: Fun little powerful problem. Often referred to as "That undercling problem" because of the powerful first move to an undercling. Start with a bad right hand crimp on the arete, and a left hand side pull crimp way down low. Throw a series of powerful moves to the lip generally following the arete, and top out.
content.location: On the left arete of the Triangle Slab boulder, starting under the little overhang on it. The boulder rests just upstream of "Dr. Jones", but down stream from "Fortune and Glory".

content.description: Start on small crimp left of the main arete with good foot. Make hard reach to good rail, then hike your feet up and continue to the top.
content.location: On the Snake Eyes boulder, left of the main arete where "Snake Eyes" tops out.

content.description: Start on some gastons just right of the right side arete of the boulder. continue up the arete using sparse holds on the face to eventually reach the top of the triangle. Top out.
content.location: On the right arete of the triangle slab boulder. The boulder rests just upstream of "Dr. Jones", but down stream from "Fortune and Glory".

content.description: Begin on the same hold as "Steel Head", and work right, beginning with a big move. Power through sloping ledges and some big moves to be rewarded with a juggy top out.
content.location: On the Spider Dojo boulder, which is slightly uphill from the trail, approx. 50 yards uphill of the river. Upstream from "The Pharaoh", downstream from the Snake Eyes boulder.

content.description: Start on the same hold as "Temple of Hank", the sloping jug on the far left side of the boulder. Power straight up through some committing moves on holds that take some skin, with a balancy move just before the lip.
content.location: On the Spider Dojo boulder, which is slightly uphill from the trail, approx. 50 yards uphill of the river. Upstream from "The Pharaoh", downstream from the Snake Eyes boulder.

content.description: Start way back in the little cave on the farthest jug on the left (often slimy). Work out a jug shelf to some tough compression moves getting over the bulge. Juggy top out.
content.location: On the Spider Dojo boulder, which is slightly uphill from the trail, approx. 50 yards uphill of the river. Upstream from "The Pharaoh", downstream from the Snake Eyes boulder.

content.description: Start down and right on the lowest jug. Work up and left through a series of jug and sloper shelves to top out at the arete all the way on the left.
content.location: First boulder you come across on the walk in.

content.description: Direct start to Fortune and Glory. Start on two sidepulls below the cool ledge feature. The left hand is almost always wet and slimy. Work up to the ledge/ rail feature, then finish up Fortune and Glory.
content.location: On the hike to boulders farther downstream. Upstream from Triangle Slab boulder, but downstream from the Spider Dojo boulder.

content.description: A great problem, but very height dependent, and poor rock quality. Start at the base of the block, and use compression to get to the obvious jug shelf on the left. Bail onto that shelf if you don't want a high top out, or continue to the top for the full problem.
content.location: One of the most uphill problems, yet a very obvious block shaped boulder with graffiti letters spelling "SAMO" on it. Slightly downstream and uphill of the Spider Dojo boulder.

content.description: Start left on a sloping shelf, and work right through a cool ledge feature, topping out up a sequential shield, awesome movement!
content.location: On the hike to boulders farther downstream. Upstream from Triangle Slab boulder, but downstream from the Spider Dojo boulder.

content.description: Start matched on the far right small crimp rail. Work left past some sharp holds with bad feet and high tension heel hooks. Use the arete all the way on the left to top out.
content.protection: Pads (maybe have someone there to watch that they don't slide into the river).
content.location: One of the last boulders you come across. The problem faces the river and sits atop another boulder. Just upstream from "The Art of Zen", and just downstream from the triangle shaped slab boulder.

content.description: Start as far back as you can in the roof like overhang on a jug (your feet might be over the river). Work through great jug shelves to a reachy crux just below the lip. Easy top out.
content.protection: Pads (watch that they don't slide into the river).
content.location: The most downstream route you'll probably go to. A boulder or two downstream from Dr. Jones and the triangle slab boulder. Right on the river.

content.description: Some fun boulders of good quality for Ohio climbing. A small but dense area of boulders ranging in difficulty from V0 to V9 (currently, potential for harder problems). Most problems get shade in the morning, and sun in the afternoon.
